51.48.text:
Bow hunting has become
a very popular sport

53.62.text:
in the last few decades and
more than 200,000 people

56.79.text:
hunt deer with a bow
every fall in Wisconsin.

59.69.text:
It might surprise you to
know that modern bow hunting

62.09.text:
actually started right
here in Wisconsin.

64.83.text:
On a visit to the
Wisconsin bow hunting

66.70.text:
Heritage Foundation Museum,
we talked with Bill McCrary,

70.54.text:
author of the History
of Wisconsin bow hunting

72.74.text:
and learned about our state's
rich bow hunting heritage.

77.94.text:
archery and bow hunting started
with the Native Americans

81.95.text:
and for them it was survivalist
and marshal in nature.

94.23.text:
And that's when sort of speak,
the white men took it over

98.06.text:
and they wanted to
go deer hunting.

100.63.text: At first, it was target archery,

103.27.text:
and then in 1930, the
first non Native American

108.37.text:
killed a deer with
a bow and arrow

113.15.text:
His name was Roy Case,
he was from Racine.

116.75.text:
And he had to get
special permission

119.72.text:
from the Wisconsin Conservation
Department to do that.

124.66.text:
In 1934, the first bow and
arrow season came about.

129.60.text:
And Wisconsin was the
first state in the nation

133.77.text:
to allow an archery
only deer season.

141.01.text:
And that was kind of established
our leadership position

146.35.text:
and we actually have
never relinquished that.

150.38.text:
The archery deer's
seasons really took off

156.26.text:
Back then, the deer
season was in December.

159.16.text:
It opened December 1,
1930, it ran for 10 days.

166.30.text:
we have here, the taxidermy
mount of that first deer.

171.84.text:
And we also have the
bow that Roy used

175.74.text:
and the arrow that Roy used
to take that first deer.

180.21.text:
We do have the Hall
of Fame members.

183.62.text:
Probably the most well
known is Aldo Leopold.

186.65.text: And we do have a display

188.82.text:
of original Aldo
Leopold archery tackle.

192.76.text:
It was tackle that he
made back in the 1930s.

197.16.text:
Art LaHa was a very famous
Wisconsin bow hunter.

201.30.text:
He was from the Vilas
County area of the state,

207.27.text:
He had a bow hunting camp,
where bow hunters would come

211.08.text:
in the fall and then he would
guide them on their hunts.

216.05.text:
Actually, it was probably
the best one in Wisconsin.

219.99.text:
There were hunters that
came from across the nation

223.06.text:
to hunt with Art
up in Vilas County.

225.82.text:
Of the Hall of Fame
members that we have,

229.93.text:
Norm Delaney is the,
actually the only one

234.80.text:
He was an engineer by
trade and this allowed him

242.88.text: to create the first compound bow

246.68.text: that was ever made in Wisconsin.

250.05.text:
We have that compound
bow here in the museum

256.82.text:
Another one of our prominent
Hall of Fame members,

262.76.text:
Larry started in the late
1920s in northern Wisconsin,

268.03.text:
he was the recreational
director at a camp

271.07.text:
in northern Wisconsin
and he had his campers

277.44.text:
including bows and
arrows up there.

283.75.text:
where he established LC Whiffen

287.85.text:
and it became one of the
biggest archery companies

292.83.text:
He made bows, arrows, bow

298.16.text:
Whiffen Archery just
about made it all

Larry Whiffen Sr. was
involved directly with

309.58.text:
the Wisconsin Bow hunters

313.15.text:
as a vice president,
and as a president.

316.78.text: John Schoenike was a bow hunter

324.92.text:
which went on to
become a very large

331.26.text:
A very large archery
company in the Midwest,

He and Whiffen in Milwaukee

with each other, but it
was a friendly competition,

342.98.text:
but they both knew if they
were going to succeed,

So they worked together
to promote the sport.

John Schoenike was a
man that had a knack

for getting people to

360.19.text:
He started, he
with a few others,

started a number of clubs

He promoted local

376.81.text:
And he was a man that

to archery and to bow

and because of the products

John Schoenike had a

He was the first one to

to a bow through some

how the Wisconsin Bow

preserve and protect

1507.24.text:
Join us again next week
for Outdoor Wisconsin.

1546.74.text:
♪ Long I've loved the
owl in the evening

1549.55.text:
♪ Moon on the lake
and muskee on the line

1554.82.text:
♪ Free yourself like
an eagle in the air

1557.39.text:
♪ Feed yourself like a
bear in the blackberry

1567.00.text:
♪ When the work or
life is way too much

♪ You're in too deep
way out of touch

♪ Lace up your boots,
get out of town

1574.81.text:
♪ A walk in the wild,
sit down and listen

1579.11.text:

of the crisp of the night

1584.02.text:
♪ Coyote brother
howling in the moonlight

do what you want to
